Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story: I was at the register, scanning groceries for Mrs. Patel, when I glanced at the clock and remembered tomorrow was trash pickup day. My neighbor, Mr. Lee, had asked me earlier if I could wait until the bins were full before putting them out, so we wouldn’t clutter the curb. Our shared bin was only half-full, but I knew if I didn’t take it out tonight, I’d miss the pickup—my shift tomorrow started before sunrise. As a neighbor, I wanted to respect Mr. Lee’s wishes and keep our shared space tidy. But as a cashier, I couldn’t just leave my post; I had to stay focused, make sure every item scanned correctly, and keep the line moving. My mind kept drifting to the bin outside, wondering if I should sneak out during my break or just leave it for next week. The pressure of doing right by Mr. Lee and not letting down my manager or the customers made my chest tight. I could feel the weight of both roles pulling me in opposite directions, and I didn’t know which expectation I should meet.
